comment._content: This must be one of your earliest photos.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Is it Carrickbrennan? It looks a bit rural to be one of the churchyards in Dun Laoghaire.

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: Here, maybe: maps.osi.ie/publicviewer/#V1,723292,728193,7,7

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Pretty early alright if it is early 1860s for a photo on our Commons stream. This is one of our earliest on here for which we have an exact date - 10th November 1863, but the very lovely Miss Coddington dates from circa 1852...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: I wonder where it was? I don't see it on the OS historical maps. From Wikipedia article on Dean's Grange (founded 1861): The Burial Act of 1855 resulted in the closure of many of the older churchyards in Dublin and surrounds due to overcrowding. This drove the need to find new lands for cemeteries.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: There's a companion double showing a ruined church - catalogue.nli.ie/Record/STP_0746/Image?lookfor=http://www...

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Not at all sure on location beyond Kingstown as an area. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] may be right as one of our Facebookers queried:  "Is that Carrickbrennan near Monkstown Castle? Nearly impaled myself clearing ivy from ancestors's railings - watched by the curious resident fox!"
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: I would concur with the Carrickbrennan churchyard suggestion (Which would make the "companion double" subject Saint Mochanna's church). Seems to stack up with MARC description and subject. If not verified/verifiable by the graves, it could also be Rathmichael

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: That is a busy place, people must be dying to get in! haha

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/66151649@N02] I know that's intended for levity, and I don't mean to take from that, but if you look at the dates, you will note that most fall around the late 1840s to early 1860s. People were dying of starvation in those years. Personally I hope someone was left to mourn poor John Stone (who must've been quite young when he lost his parents - I imagine in fact the cross was erected somewhat later as he was probably in his early teens (max) when he lost his mother).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
A gentleman over on our Facebook page commented:
"It was at the bottom of what we called the Widow Gambles Hill, on the same side as the Christian Brothers College. Not very well looked after. We played in there as kids 55 years ago."
I think that's somewhere around Mounttown Road Upper, as that's where CBC Monkstown is - unfortunately Widow Gambles (excellently named) Hill does not compute in Google Maps...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 66151649@N02

comment.author: 20727502@N00

I guess sometimes it's nice to find that balance between "having the craic" and what are otherwise potentially dry and sobering subjects...

comment.author: 66151649@N02
comment._content: I like the taste of my foot in my mouth anyway... lol. Ask my wife/boss/friends...

comment.author: 36399905@N04
comment._content: This photograph, and a related stereo pair has been identified by the staff at the Archives & Research Centre of the Genealogical Society of Ireland as being the old Catholic Cemetery at Kill o' the Grange which was closed by ministerial order in 1864.  - See Ireland's Genealogical Gazette October 2013 (ISSN 1649-7937)

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: This one, perhaps, in Google maps and OSI.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The gazette has a webpage, but it'll be a few months before that issue is up by the looks of it.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The streetview of the ruined church is recognizable as the companion / related stereo pair - catalogue.nli.ie/Record/STP_0746/Image?lookfor=http://www... The ruined church by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/89309118@N03] who has relatives buried in the graveyard - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/89309118@N03/8131581366]

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: OK, compare the church in the companion stereo pair in the nli archive with pics of the ruin at Kill O' The Grange like this one It is definitely the same building, this is Kill O' The Grange, marked as Grange Church on the 1837 map. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Snap!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Ha! Great minds ...

Due to the angle of the shadows and Christian burial convention of feet to the east,  this photo must be looking west - I would suggest that it is from the footpath marked on the NE of the graveyard (See OSI link above).  Which might mean that the stone wall in the background is part of the Grange Church, although covered in vegetation (see note).

comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/boibowl] Interesting. Apparently Deansgrange library holds a list of inscriptions from Kill o' the Grange (Clonkeen / St Finians) in its local history section, so if anyone is a member/local* it might be worth a look. To see if there is a match with any of "our" grave markers. (* It's nearly 30 years since I took a book out from Deansgrange library - I doubt my card is still valid...)

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Thinking that upright pale gravestone is a fairly good match with the one in [http://www.flickr.com/photos/colm-jackson/]'s photo above.  In a similar position at the bend in the footpath.
